Mice are used because they are the closest mammal model that are easy to work on, are cheap, are well understood, easy to care for, are easy to breed, and easy to give cancer. But there have been a LOT of promising mouse studies that didn’t work when transferred to humans.

>90% of cancer deaths are because of metastases which are extremely small and difficult to find. I don't see how this conjugate would be any good for treating metastases in humans. A lot of the problem for treating metastases is that metastases in mice are verrrry large compared to one in humans and the chances of a given drug/treatment "finding" a metastases to attack/suppress are comparatively very high. I see this being a potentially great treatment for primary tumours though.

3:19 "CpG oligodeoxynucleotide" is just another way of saying "a small piece of DNA that is just a whole bunch of C and G repeats (so like CGCGCGCGCGCGCGCG)".

A piece of DNA consisting of a bunch of the same letters (like a whole bunch A's, or, as in this case, a bunch of repeating units of 2 or 3 letters) tend to have some special functions. Among other things, these DNA regions/pieces can be a signal, a docking site for other things, or a new structure (e.g. when the DNA loops back onto itself).

This is a great summary of a scientific research however there are a few errors. T cells do not have receptors for CpG. The receptor, called TLR9, is however found on antigen-presenting cells. These cells are part of the innate immune response. They attack and engulf pathogens and then present them to the adaptive branch of the immune system, the T cells. CpG can induce cytokine secretion by antigen-presenting cells which in turn induces OX40 expression on T cells. Then the antibody binds to T cells and mimic the ligand of OX40 which activates the T cells.

Oh, Caitlin, Alyssa, Christie, and Hank! Realy!!??! Preventative. If 'preventative' were a real word it would be an adjective derived from the verb 'preventate' which does not exist. The real word you ought to have written (and Hank should have had the sense to use) is 'preventive'. It is derived from the verb 'prevent' (a real word that does exist) that means exactly what you want that fake word to mean. Do we say a person is 'selectative'? Do surgeons say a surgery is 'electative'? Of course not. Why? They are not real adjectives because 'selectate' and 'electate' are not real verbs. Even your spell-checker knows that. You may find 'preventative' in a dictionary because so many people use it, but if your dictionary doesn't simply direct you to 'preventive', or if it in any way encourages its use, burn it immediately! And that goes for 'orientate', too.
